text:
RT @ShaneAParrish: A lot of people think that we shouldn't trust others by default because someone might screw us over.

It's been my exper…
@syedanasbaqi His full quote appears in the next tweet and that quote isn’t about people. The people aspect is my addition for software products, where it’s essential.
@Disco_Jen Middle management, done right, can definitely make a big impact on the company. Congrats and all the best for your new role!
@CoVisual Not personally

Let’s see a quick example.

Say you’re crafting content for your product’s landing page.

Your customers’ subconscious questions:
1) What does it do?
2) Is it for me?
3) How good is it?
4) Should I act now?

Let your content help them answer these questions.

Nudge, don’t push.

When writing to influence someone, consider their subconscious questions upfront.

Then craft content that makes it trivially easy for *them* to arrive at the answers to those questions.

Give them that satisfaction and you might just win them over.
@iamsooraj @sachinrekhi That's an unsolved problem currently, but is eminently tractable and so I hope it doesn't remain unsolved in the future.

@lisiwong It's hard. It helps to establish extremely high credibility with them so they give you more space than they would otherwise (in return for you making them look good via the outputs & outcomes your product achieves). But that likely only works for ~10% of people.

@sachinrekhi Half life of content on Twitter is quite short vs. blogs. IME reach on Twitter vs. a blog (if starting from scratch) is exceptionally high. Can't speak for a longstanding blog. My take is: post threads on Twitter first, take the best threads & turn them into blog posts.

And I must emphasize, Irrational doesn't always mean Frivolous. It can be a feature that delivers great user value (e.g Gmail's "did you forget to attach the file"), but may not have had enough business justification.

How to start, if it sounds too hard:
https://t.co/rRRWZgLFla

@vingar Start somewhere & go from there. 10%. If that's too high, 5%. If that doesn't work, try 2% (which would be about 10 hrs per person in a quarter).

And I don't mean just frivolous features. You can build something of real value to users, even if it isn't "rational" priority-wise.

Probably the most important thing I can say about management per character of text.

The ranking is really important here: Ears, and therefore Listening, comes first and foremost.

It’s what Pressfield calls Resistance (in The War of Art). https://t.co/yjgMaWNQtS
If you found this model useful/interesting, you might like this one, for product managers and other leaders: https://t.co/GnA2PFRCxT
@shriyanevatia Congrats! This thread captures some of my thoughts on management, hope it’s useful. https://t.co/LslHlJ5DZh
@mar15sa This is part of an bigger piece on Tactical vs. Strategic, so maybe it'll appear in a longer thread in the future.
@JonathanAGraham Not sure, but in work settings, a How-first and a Who-first approach overlap quite a lot.

@sh_reya All the best and do share how it goes.
👍🏾

Each has upsides & downsides.

No right answer.

You do you.

But for greater success:

-Identify your default

-Consider why it’s the default

-Consider when it’s harmful

-Consider current context

-Try a different mode if it feels right

-Evaluate if it works

-Then repeat

📈

People can be:

1) How-first
2) What-first
3) Why-first

How-first people execute well.

What-first people create well.

Why-first people lead well.

https://t.co/eagA1kJOBA

@dvdmmc Decouple "Internal Release Target" from "External Commitment Date". IRT can change as the situation evolves, a change to the ECD requires deeper discussion & cross-functional buy-in. Team leaders (EM/PM) must then ensure that team members don't view ECD as the real IRT (not easy)

@gem_ray Ultimate onus is indeed on company execs to not use stupid shortcuts like "this team hits all their dates" to evaluate team competence. That's why it's great to work in companies whose execs are competent & emotionally mature. And also draining to work where that isn't the case.

@gem_ray For sure. When such stupid games are being played in an org, a team leader can choose to either "master the game" (bad) or "play it just barely enough to stay in it" (optimal given the situation). The latter requires courage & conviction to do right by the customer. Not common.
@jbellack Ah, that’s a nice tactic.

@johncutlefish Thanks for sharing these threads.

And I'll say that your files are much more comprehensive than mine 🙂

@billboulger A delay does disrupt go-to-market teams, so there's surely a cost to it. In many companies, a delay is a major catalyst for finger-pointing between (already stressed) teams. People want to avoid getting called out & embarrassed in such situations, adding to the allergy to delays.

@SiVola Smart sales teams will usually create a buffer when “committing” an availability date to an enterprise customer. The original tweet was referring to internally-committed release dates, not externally-committed availability dates. Agree with your general point about customer focus

Show me a product team that proudly & precisely hits all of its release dates and I will show you a team that excessively pads its schedule and cares more about internal impression management than product impact.

The difference between the two?

A delay is immediately visible to everyone, an ill-conceived feature is obvious only to the discerning product eye.

A delay is rarely consequential, an ill-conceived feature left undetected can profoundly damage the product’s prospects.

👇🏾

The tragedy of most product organizations is that a 3 week delay for a product launch will cause much greater stress & scrutiny than an ill-conceived feature in the very same product.

👇🏾
@geetharganesh Thank you. I'll be posting it to LinkedIn at some point and a video recording of this talk should also be available soon.

surely many more than a handful will be successful despite all odds.

Back to the top of this thread:
https://t.co/7gl89Kqrq7

But perhaps even more importantly, I hope that our shared journey today will help you build happier & more capable product teams and more satisfied customers.

And for that, I wish you all the best.

Thank you very much for your time.

❤️

And with that, I hope that this thread is helpful when you're scoping a project next week, when you are making major prioritization decisions for annual planning, and when you’re devising a new product strategy next year.

Note that this need not be one-size-fits all. You likely don’t need each of these operating principles. 

That’s where context is important. Identify which biases your teams are most susceptible to, and adopt the corresponding operating principles accordingly.

And lastly, leaders should counteract the Authority Approval bias by fostering a culture of Constructive Dissonance—which is about going after the right answer, and not to just try to prove ourselves right.
To avoid getting killed in a game of Russian Roulette for products is to understand that Preventing Catastrophe is better than having to do Heroics to save the day afterwards.

To counteract Maslow’s Hammer, we need to recognize that Context comes first. 

The same tool can either help us or harm us, and the way we decide is with an appreciation of our current context.

The antidote for the Execution Orientation Fallacy is to cultivate high ambition and high agency—to seek what's impactful not just what's convenient, to find a way to get what you want, without waiting for conditions to be perfect or otherwise blaming the circumstances.
To fight the Bias-for-Building fallacy, we need to recognize that sheer Speed doesn’t mean much unless it’s in the right direction. That is why Velocity is what really matters.
To counteract the IKEA Effect for products, we need a culture of rigorous thinking, or reasoning from first principles.

Second, name it to tame it.

Make your teams more aware of these biases, by name. 

Add these names to your team's shared vocabulary so you can create mutual awareness and accountability while ensuring psychological safety for everyone.

As with most things in life, we need to start with Self Awareness. Recognize that these biases are real & each of us susceptible to them. If we sense ourselves falling prey to one of them, that doesn't mean we are stupid—that recognition is the key that unlocks greater wisdom. https://t.co/GuWjYEVKcx
In this last part, we’ll take a look at the 3 main ways that we can combat these biases as product people and as leaders within a product organization. https://t.co/c0JSe8liuw

So there you have it.

You now know what I’ve observed across many companies of all sizes over the past 15 years and what took me the last 4 years of introspection, inquiry, and research to fully understand. https://t.co/meZtWzVnBK

text:
And lastly, the Authority Approval Bias, where we devise products and plans based on what’s going to be easier to get us approval or confirm the pre-existing beliefs of an executive.

We aim for a “successful product review meeting” at the expense of a “successful product”. https://t.co/PHfsBpuAYE

Russian Roulette for products is especially common in companies where moving fast & breaking things is viewed as a virtue. It's also common in companies where "following orders" is expected & rewarded.

Pre-mortems are a good antidote for Russian Roulette for products. https://t.co/yx4FeLDyJk

And the answer is that such teams are likely affected by the next bias, Russian Roulette for products.
 
In it, we don’t account enough for scenarios that could, under certain conditions, lead to a catastrophic outcome for our product or a PR nightmare for our company. https://t.co/yujdrsB0m5

We often encounter situations where ANOTHER company’s product is a fiasco. 

And when look at such a situations, we might ask ourselves: 
What was the product team thinking?

How did they miss something so big, so harmful & obvious? https://t.co/Bend73NMws

Consistency, process, data are often used as hammers at companies.

Now, data isn't bad, process isn't bad.
 
The main point is that our decisions must first be informed by the context, not by a tool, a process, or a best practice that may have worked for us in another context. https://t.co/wOQlzGOkCE
https://t.co/kOrvb1nkc7

Now, on to our next bias. This one’s named after Abraham Maslow, who needs no introduction.
 
One relatively little known aspect of his legacy is called Maslow’s Hammer: if the only tool you have is a hammer, you will treat everything as if it is a nail. https://t.co/mdOhO9X9OP

This one is common in product cultures where shipping something—anything—is lauded & rewarded.

When I talk to PM leaders & startup CEOs, it comes up all the time. They want their teams to think bigger, not be fazed by current limitations. They want their ppl to have High Agency. https://t.co/SVVTGIdujD

The Bias-for-Building Fallacy is most common in orgs that worship speed. That's fine, but if you go speedily in the wrong direction, you will end up in the wrong place. That’s why teams should value velocity much more than speed: velocity being a combo of speed & direction. https://t.co/LOsvmAhJTZ

This is the most common bias I see, especially on high-energy teams & ambitious startups. We can’t stand the idea of taking a couple more weeks to get the product spec or experience right upfront & we end up building something sub-optimal. And the IKEA Effect kicks in after that. https://t.co/uIerKvsAv7

It comes from the observation that something we’ve built together with our own hands is more valuable to us than if we had to purchase exactly the same item pre-assembled. https://t.co/KkwvfS0HqE

text:
Here are some ways this bias can manifest in team discussions.

I want you to note that, no single one of these is by itself a definitive sign of this bias, but I suggest keeping your eyes and ears open when these things are said repeatedly by you or your team. https://t.co/5jzsUotWi4

While Kahneman was prolly talking about everyday life, 
the Focusing Illusion applies to products too. It's one of the biases I see quite often. It’s common because it’s largely invisible.

Companies that think of themselves as customer-driven are especially susceptible to it. https://t.co/mTQWZbtRES
The first one being: The Focusing Illusion, first described by Daniel Kahneman. https://t.co/mgUbHdrs55
Anyway, back to our story, there are at least 3 biases that got in the way of Andy, Kris, Jo and team here.
This Customer Problems Stack Rank (CPSR) acts as a great test of the TRUE priority of the customer problem & the product solution you’re discussing.

After talking to each customer about the problem of support costs, he should have asked them to stack rank that problem vs. all the other problems they were trying to solve for their business & for their organization.

THAT is where the real truth could have emerged.

That is why these customers could never find the time or resources to actually adopt & deploy the product when it was ready.

Here’s what Andy should have done instead:

When Andy talked to customers about the specific problem of customer support costs, they naturally “focused” on that problem.

And with that Focus on a specific problem, they excluded other, more important problems they were facing.

So… what really happened here? 

Now clearly, there can be many possible causes for product failure.

But in this case, the main observation is a simple one: 

This product should not have been built in the first place. https://t.co/D10pN0xjSh

Now, at this point:

Learnings are captured and shared widely in the org

"We haven't failed, we have learned”

Of course, Edison’s lightbulb quote is repeated several times

“I haven’t failed, I’ve just found 10,000 ways that won’t work” https://t.co/7Lj2Coec3M

So finally, at the next product review, almost 3 years after work began, a decision is made:

It’s time to sunset this product. https://t.co/rD4NuGv87o

They go ahead and make the changes on the GTM front. Another year goes by. 

Adoption is STILL flat. https://t.co/8HKK5IV6C3

Andy, still very customer-centric, says: 
“We know from talking to customers that we have the right product. We just need to improve our Go-To-Market strategy & execution”

Kris & Jo discuss ideas to improve GTM approach: bundling, re-org the Sales team, pricing, etc. https://t.co/MGQhRqzSjI

The team takes 6 more months to build features X, Y, and Z.

Adoption is still not nearly where it needs to be. Flat.

Time for another product review. https://t.co/q7KDNBpQP4

It’s now time for a product review with the exec team.

At the review, Andy directs attention towards the positives. 

Here’s what we’ve learned:
Our MVP isn’t sufficient.
We need to make it easier to adopt. 
We need features X, Y, and Z

Kris, the CPO, gives the go-ahead. https://t.co/uWivDYmWHQ

Andy now goes back to the customers who had expressed interest in the product early on: "the product is ready for deployment".
And then he waits.
And he waits some more.
And then some more.

Unfortunately, even 6 months after its initial launch, barely any customer adoption. https://t.co/fR37UNfvCb
The team works hard, executes almost flawlessly on v1 and launches it in just 6 months. https://t.co/FYfzKGVCUP

Let's start with a product story.

Once upon a time, a team has a new product idea.

The team is very customer-driven & they talk to customers about their product hypothesis. 

Customers sound very excited, so Andy & team get the mandate to build out version 1 of the product. https://t.co/ywrO17QLZX
https://t.co/swzjr4nAfz

Let's let Charlie Munger drive this point home.

For a sufficiently smart & motivated group of individuals, decision-making is less about making brilliant choices, and much more about avoiding bad ones.

And THAT is why we need to study the biases that stymie us as product people https://t.co/vkaXEbBF7e

We can all appreciate what the person on the left is saying about making effective decisions.

That's all well and good, but what the person to the right is saying is equally important. And that is: to avoid making bad choices. https://t.co/UEppBRWhGH

So, if you show me 10 teams with similar ability and ask me which one will produce more wins over the long term?

I’ll tell you that it’s the team that makes the most effective decisions.
Lastly: https://t.co/Nc5g3Zjk2v
Annual planning is useful, but the decisions you make while creating your product strategy will determine your long-term success more than your annual plan. https://t.co/t6MXr2CBAR
Similarly: https://t.co/fHa1EJgY3v
That’s why I like to say—you do not rise to the level of your plan. It’s easy to make a great-looking plan—you fall to the level of your decision-making. https://t.co/o3N39PPo0q

text:
And THAT is where Decisions come in.

Mind you, we make countless decisions while building, enhancing and marketing our products.

The quality of those Decisions is ultimately what determines the impact that our product makes. https://t.co/7W9IQplWmp

To answer that, let’s start with the Inputs—Outputs—Outcomes framework. Within the scope of this framework, our challenge is simple, though not easy.

Our challenge is:
How do we collect the right Inputs, convert them to the right Outputs, so we can get to the right Outcomes? https://t.co/o6Y1sfK1Rh
https://t.co/UfLNiS32iT

This thread is my answer to that question. 

And it has to do with the biases of product teams when building products.

3 parts to this thread: https://t.co/pI2pFcDSnG
It all started when I asked myself this question in the year 2016: https://t.co/Ml8aE8cVXh

Product failure is expensive.

And look around, it’s common.

Why do products fail?

Is it becos we can't build the product?
No

Is it becos we launched it N weeks late?
Almost never

So what is it?

The 7 Biases of Product teams, a very visual thread: https://t.co/tXMmXd8zu7

@descopemore Agree, they aren’t mutually exclusive. It’s about what’s prioritized/valued more. https://t.co/xfQA3waiTs

Basic, but important:

Product teams should rarely prioritize Efficiency higher than Effectiveness. And yet so many do

How to tell them apart:

Teams that value Efficiency obsess over Speed & Process

Teams that value Effectiveness obsess over Customer Problems & Differentiation

@HaggsTheRed @TheLifeofThane Glad you liked it. It's from the book "15 Commitments of Conscious Leadership", which I very much recommend for leaders at all levels.
@JavierInchausti Thank you so much. Glad you enjoyed it!

@kush_apoorva Perhaps it's "start with" instead of "focus on"?

Regarding selling in particular, some people can start with Principles and deduce the right Tactics based on the context. Although I agree Tactics seem to be the most popular starting place.
@akshayleo25 That sounds nice. If you can, do send a link when you've finished it.

To improve in any area, we need:

The Mindset
The Principles
The Tactics

Just 1 of these = A start
Any 2 = Progress
Aligning all 3 = Mastery

Mindset > Principles > Tactics
(by importance)

Tactics > Principles > Mindset
(by popularity)

Seek the important, not just the popular.

urls.title: Avoiding Stupidity is Easier than Seeking Brilliance
urls.description: It's often easier to avoid stupidity rather than trying to be brilliant. Read this article to learn when to avoid stupidity and when to pursue brilliance.

text:
Why talk about what not to do?

Why not just focus on the positive?

Because we should avoid stupidity.

It's better than seeking brilliance.

For more, check out this @farnamstreet article. It's gold.

https://t.co/zHLLtfW4qB

10 tips for misery in work & life: 

-See self as a victim 

-Complain constantly

-Resent successful ppl

-Compare as a habit

-Nitpick to feel superior

-Assume bad intent

-Don’t listen to others

-Try to please ppl in power

-Aim to impress everyone

-Crave short term rewards

@iprathamesh Evaluate #1 throughout the hiring process
Probe them on #2 once you have an offer
Research #3 on your own as if you were a VC

text: @davidshreni Yep, very much endorse that approach. Once one reaches a certain degree of proficiency and repute in one’s career, they should interview the companies more than the companies interview them. A good place to be and a great privilege that I try not to take for granted.

@madgiu It has for me and many others, but YMMV. And it certainly isn’t easy. There is no one answer for these things. It’s about understanding various perspectives and making a choice for oneself based on that understanding.

@davidshreni If you’re certain they’re a bad manager from the interview process, sure, don’t join. In most cases, it’s really hard to tell with high confidence that an HM is a bad manager. People who don’t join based on HM more often base it on ego than on a conviction that the HM is bad.

@davidshreni If the hiring manager (HM) will be your manager forever & you’re somehow certain they aren’t worthy of being your manager, sure. This isn’t saying that a manager isn’t important. It’s saying that the initial HM is not as crucial as people imagine, if the other criteria hold true.

@TommayC Simple, but not easy.

Not a panacea, but a perspective.

Also, I’m clearly biased but I’ll put one tweet out here along with a link to our jobs site. Do consider applying if you want to work with great people at a high growth company in a tremendously large market that’s also growing.

If you have the privilege of picking between a number of job offers (say >5), use the analytical factors (“the spreadsheet”) to narrow your options down to 2-3 amazing companies.

But in the end, toss the spreadsheet out the window, and listen to your gut to pick THE ONE.

text:
Like any good PM, anytime I’ve started a job search, I’ve created “the spreadsheet” with the companies I’m considering, along dozens of factors, each scored & weighed.

The spreadsheet is useful, but only up to a point.

Which brings me to my last & perhaps most important point.

Over the 100s of conversations I've had, I can’t count how many blunders I've seen (including my own) because of such minor, fleeting factors

If the company very clearly meets the table-stakes & the 3 Main Criteria, I recommend ignoring almost everything else in almost all cases

And, SO WHAT if you think your hiring manager at this company would be your peer in a parallel universe?

Odds are you’ll have a new manager anyway in a fast-growth environment, 6-12 months down the road

Why let temporary ego get in the way?

Same for immediate scope, title, etc

Why?

Remember that fast growth rate is a key criterion for us.

What happens with fast growth in a company that also has great ppl?

Things change rapidly, the changes are made rigorously, & these great ppl adapt well to the changes.

And these are exactly the outcomes you want.

And if the 3 Main Criteria are a bullseye, I’d ignore other factors such as immediate manager, current org structure, starting title, # of ppl reporting to me, current importance of my role in the org....

Yes, this sounds odd, but this is where I’ve seen ppl make major mistakes.

What about a worthy mission, good culture, interesting work?

For talented ppl (say top 10%), these are actually table-stakes i.e. these ppl should disqualify companies based on them, but should rarely pick a company solely based on them if the 3 Main Criteria aren’t satisfied.

Why the 3 Main Criteria?

People: after sufficient time in the industry, you’ll conclude that ultimately it’s all about the people

Growth rate: company growth creates suitable conditions for almost everything else

Large growing market: rising tide etc., room for error recovery

I’m not surprised by that.

I was that person for a long time.

But in the vast majority of cases, I’ve observed that relying on a fancy M X N matrix of dozens of criteria for the next company to join tends to hurt more than it helps.

And I’ve personally experienced that pain.

Every year, I talk to ~50 people in my network about job changes.

Every situation is different, so there's no one-size-fits-all formula.

I don’t have all the answers.

But my overall observation is that folks, esp. the smart ones, tend to over-complicate & over-intellectualize.

I’ve made many mistakes in picking companies to join.

For talented ppl, such mistakes can be costly.

Heres what I’d tell my younger self:

Join a company with
1) the highest caliber people you can find
2) a high growth rate
3) in a large market that is itself growing

That’s why it makes sense to view everyone as equal to us—not inferior, not superior.

It isn’t just a moral ideal.

It’s a hack for more rigorous thinking.

The problem is that we evaluate the messenger much more than the message.

Great idea from someone we deem inferior?
“Show me proof!”

Terrible idea from someone we deem superior?
“How profound!”

@Nkuzilele Not one that can be publicly shared. But it can be quite straightforward.

Category 1-
metric 1.1: value 1.1
metric 1.2: value 1.2
...

Category 2-
metric 2.1: value 2.1 (% WoW change)
metric 2.2: value 2.2 (% WoW change)
...

...

Can add time series etc. but basic also works.

Lastly:
Remember to be metrics-informed, not metrics-driven.

Metrics are one of the inputs you need to make product decisions & assess progress towards your company’s mission & strategy. Also use other inputs.

Context is everything, so adapt accordingly. Okay to break rules.
📈

Bonus:

Some tactics I’ve found useful
1. Treat your metrics dashboard like a product
2. Actually track its usage (meta!)
3. Set a Chrome pinned tab for the dash
4. Review pinned tab every N days (I do it every morning)
5. Set a weekly email report (some ppl LOVE emailed metrics)

So, overall:

3-5 Key Metrics & 3-5 Leading Metrics have worked quite well for me on most products, across both B2B products and consumer products.

The 6 metrics categories introduced in this thread will help ensure you’re thinking holistically about user value & business value.

Your Leading Metrics might change more frequently than Key Metrics.
 
e.g. for the next 2-3 quarters, you might have an LM for adoption of a particular strategic feature (which over time will move your KMs), an LM for country availability, an LM for self-serve funnel success,....

In certain cases (e.g. B2B SaaS with long adoption cycles), KMs can be lagging indicators of work done (e.g. Revenue takes time)

That’s why you also need a small set of leading indicator metrics. Call them Leading Metrics (LMs). Define 3-5 LMs in addition to KMs if this applies.

Some ppl perform major metrics contortions for Key Metrics e.g. “for this, I depend on Sales, so I can't use it as a KM".

I don’t worry about having 100% control.

There's no such thing as 100% control anyway & if Sales can’t or doesn’t sell my product, that’s still MY problem.

Key Metrics (KMs) give a great bird’s-eye view of how the product is doing.

You’ll typically create annual goals/targets for your KMs.

Your company’s execs/board will also likely look at these metrics to assess the product’s progress.

The criteria I use for Key Metrics:
(a) is responsive to product changes
(b) is an aggregate measure of the product’s value for its users
(c) can be readily tied to business value 
(d) is expected to be long lasting (say at least 2-3 years)

(remember: these aren't rules)

A good heuristic from @bbalfour, related to Key Metrics

Source:
https://t.co/1iFxLlXn0x https://t.co/6MncXCy1OG

For any important product, you’ll want to track dozens of metrics (esp. in the Usage metrics category)

At the same time, define a small set of metrics (3-5) that'll be faithful indicators of your product’s progress towards its strategy & goals. Let’s call them Key Metrics (KMs).

Why these categories?
These categories cover multiple granularities & perspectives you need to consider for rigorous product decisions

Other notes
-A given metric can belong to more than 1 category
-You may skip a certain category altogether for your product. Just be intentional

6/
Outcome metrics

Key question:
What overall results are we seeing from this product?

Examples:
revenue, margin, revenue per user, active users, marketshare, transactions, % of Fortune 1000 covered,...

5/
Ecosystem metrics

Key question:
What is the macro state of the product within the domain in which it operates?

Examples:
share of wallet, 3rd party integrations, industry rank, marketshare within target segments, % of TAM,...

4/
Satisfaction metrics

Key question:
What is our customers’ overall sentiment towards the product or its main features?

Examples:
overall CSAT, new feature CSAT, support CSAT,...

3/
Adoption metrics

Key question:
Is the product (along with its key features) being used as much as we’d hope and in the ways that we’d like?

Examples:
active users, dau:mau, N of M day usage, strategic feature adoption trends, free-to-paid conversions,...

2/
Usage metrics

Key question:
How are users using the product?

Examples:
time-of-day/day-of-week trends, top N actions, funnel metrics, help docs usage, retention, password reset rate,...

1/
Health metrics

Key question:
Is the product available & performing in the manner that users would reasonably expect?

Examples:
latency, initial load time, uptime, data loss rate, http errors,...

Product metrics categories:
1. Health metrics
2. Usage metrics
3. Adoption metrics
4. Satisfaction metrics
5. Ecosystem metrics
6. Outcome metrics

When conceiving your metrics, consider each of these categories & pick the right metrics across them.

A product metrics primer👇🏾

@jeffiel What is useful:
Why we want to build this & for whom
What is its general shape
What is a high priority vs low
How we will measure usage/adoption
What are the open questions

View it as a conversation starter, not the be-all-end-all.

20/
To observe and to love.
That is all.

19/
There is no grand plan, no meaning. 
Isn’t that wonderful?

18/
Suffering shows the path to wisdom. 
Taking that path is up to us.

17/
Know that we know very little

16/
Observe without drama

15/
Less “I am [X]”. 
More “I am feeling [X]”.

14/
Own your own mind

12/
How is it possible that we are always right?

11/
Understand the Fundamental Attribution Error

10/
You have your reasons. 
They have theirs.

9/
Create your own game. 
Make it a long game.
Play that game.

8/
Achieve to end the urge to achieve

7/
Think like an owner. 
Especially if you aren’t.

6/
Learn from every person

5/
Treat people as equals. 
Don’t look up or down.

4/
Know that everyone will be forgotten

3/
Compete for energy & fun. 
Not for purpose.

2/
Resist binary thinking.
Think grey.

1/
Have high standards

Last but not least, remember:

Repetition is the most useful leadership tactic. So create an annual plan that can be repeated to & remembered by your team. Create it with key team members so there’s buy-in. Make it accessible in a short doc & adapt it as you go through 2021.

👍🏾

Over the past 10 yrs, I’ve spent ¼ the average time spent by other managers on quarterly & annual planning. I think my teams have executed reasonably well & I haven’t been fired (yet). This stuff has worked well for me, but as always, remember context is everything, so adapt away

Bonus/
Borrow from Google’s 70/20/10.

Way back in the day, Google invested 70 / 20 / 10 % of its time across search+ads / apps / big-bets. I’ve taken this simple X/Y/Z % framework to many of my teams to create clarity on where we’ll spend our time & why. Has worked quite well.

text:
5/
Remember your audience.

At most mid-size/large companies, managers tend to view executives as the chief target audience of their annual plans. Recognize that you & your team are at least equally the target audience (& ideally more). Plan MUST be credible & clear for the team.

4/
Templates work for you, you don’t work for templates.

Unless you’ll literally get fired for modifying the company-defined template (ask your boss), just change it to suit your needs. Remember, the chief goal is that the plan is sound & is clear to everyone involved.

3/
Identify top N dependencies & resolve those first.

Prioritize. Don’t be afraid to escalate when you can’t get commitment on a major dependency with another team/org. This stuff is high leverage & needs your attention. This is where you need to aim for a near-perfect outcome.

2/
Avoid false precision for numeric targets.

This is where the bulk of the time is wasted. Often, people LOVE doing this because it makes them feel & look smart. Know that good enough is good enough, there's NO WAY to accurately predict certain numbers. Ditto for release dates.

1/ 
Have a strategy.

Can’t emphasize how important this is. Annual planning can be a lot of work for teams that don’t have a compelling, agreed-upon strategy. For those that do, a large part of planning is mapping the existing strategy to what’ll be done next year. Easy peasy.

In the next few weeks, the much-dreaded annual planning exercise will take over the lives of managers across most tech companies.

A thread on how to make annual planning less stressful, more useful & perhaps even fun:

Framework thinking secret:
Always Decompose

Practical steps:
1. Observe the thing
2. Get others' POV on it
3. Break it down to its elements
4. Name these elements
5. Make the names evocative
6. Assess current context
7. Ask which elements matter
8. Prioritize them
9. Go execute https://t.co/2tWhI1IJbx

text:
@Suhail Stripe did not have people with the Product Manager title for several years.

First person with the PM title was hired in 2015 (5 years after founding).

But.... there were people that were performing the PM role before that and were clearly doing that quite well.

Role ≠ Title

Tip:
You can use @readwiseio to save the Good Product Managers, Great Product Managers thread to make it easy to get a periodic reminder.

@Joey_DeBruin On your point about % of project time counting towards self-development time:

I find that it's a squandered opportunity for many PMs & leaders. They might do a good job on the project, but they don't step away enough from the project to take all the lessons that can be captured.

A direct link to the top of the Good Product Managers, Great Product Managers thread:
https://t.co/d2Rp0vDFEd

@Joey_DeBruin Agree, project learning is very valuable.

I'd still say that PMs should spend a meaningful chunk of time learning outside projects.

Reason: projects create constraints around the learning e.g. one can't learn superb product sense on an execution-heavy project.

Hence do both.

@prajwalsheno I've talked about aspects of it e.g. the LNO Effectiveness framework.

However, Cal Newport has written an excellent book on this, so I recommend that first. IIRC @sajithpai has written a great summary of that book.

text:
Love this visual
https://t.co/hVNzdbrW04

If you’ve gotten this far, do read through folks' responses here. Some have articulated this stuff much better than I could. And as always, I hope this approach of question-based inquiry was useful for the folks who participated. I might make it a regular thing if folks like it🙂

Btw, same advice when you get feedback on things you’re failing at as their leader. Profusely thank them for it (whether or not you agree), tell them that you welcome such feedback in the future too.

THEN get to the content. Ask questions, probe, debate. 

But do thank first.

Ask about root cause, options, ways to help, how to prevent such things in the future. Ask how they’re feeling about the situation

But first, make it clear that you welcome being informed about bad news

If you fail at this, you’ll unwittingly create a culture of mild dishonesty

I don’t care how bad the situation is, there's always time to say Thank You

I know that some Go Getter leaders are keen to problem-solve. To add value

But first, acknowledge the courage that was required to flag the bad news. Appreciate it. Mean it

Then, move on to the content

Alright, the correct answer is D

In almost every such situation, the first words out of a senior leader’s mouth (after they’ve understood the situation, done a “tell me more” or two as needed) should be “Thank you for sharing this with me” or its variant. And you need to mean it

@shinguardian Love listening!

Assume for this case that the listening has happened. What are your first words after that?

@pcrowe How might those variations change the first words out of the leader's mouth upon hearing about this? Should those variations matter for the first words? (they'd certainly matter for the ensuing discussion, but the question is about the very first words uttered by the leader)

Remember, the question is:

What should *literally be the first words out of your mouth* when you hear about this significant delay for an important product launch? 

i.e. the question is not about what the ensuing discussion will be

[response disallowed]
G) Who is to blame for this delay?
F) Why didn’t we know about this sooner?
E) How are you feeling about this?
D) Thank you for sharing this with me.
C) How can I help you with this?
B) Are you sure about this?
A) What’s the root cause for the delay?

You’re a Director/VP. A manager in your org tells you that an important launch is delayed by 8 wks. Your first words:

A) What’s the root cause?
B) Are you sure?
C) How can I help?
D) Thank you for sharing this
E) How are you feeling?
F) Why didn’t we know sooner?

7. Write a user story

text:
The Mind is a gift.
It catalyzes creativity.
It organizes insight.
It can be tamed when it feels secure.
It can be trained with presence.

The Mind is an able assistant.
And The Self its employer.
~

The Mind resists the Self.
It feels judged by it.
It may cede control at times. 
It never stays vanquished.
The Mind is relentless & ruthless.

The Mind is a manipulator.
It presents fiction as truth.
It distracts with the future.
It detracts with the past.
The Mind is a mirage for the true Self.

The Mind desires superiority.
It kindles this desire with comparison.
It fuels it with envy, contempt.
It douses it with self-doubt.
The Mind revels in this paradox.

The Mind and The Self:

The Mind enjoys problem-solving.
It seeks drama to feel useful.
It creates conflict to feel busy.
It solves difficulties to feel validated.
The Mind is addicted to problems.
👇🏾

This is why it's important to include Questions in one's approach to leadership, in addition to Critique, Answers & Solutions. In most cases, Questions should be the biggest component.

When using Questions, be careful not to come across as annoying. Exude genuine curiosity.

Last & certainly not the least, I hope this tweet is a useful example of the sheer power of asking the Right Question.

I intentionally did not share 𝘮𝘺 Answer upfront because you'll gain much more from mulling over the Question than from the best explanation I could provide.

What you discuss in your meetings doesn't kill you.

It's what you persistently 𝘢𝘷𝘰𝘪𝘥  discussing that kills you.

All that said, remember that context is everything.

So even if E is not the right answer for your org & team, exploring what the answer is in your specific situation will help illuminate blind-spots & bring about improvement.

Why?

Why is E rare & why is it vital?

As some folks pointed out, E is often the source of all other problems.

It's rarely discussed because no layer in the org wants to take ownership of poor decision-making.

Executives should, but requires high trust among them. That too is rare.

OK, here's my take:

D & F are quite commonly discussed. D at almost every company. F at companies that aren't market leaders.

A, B, C, E are more rare.

E is rarest in my experience, then B.

Only time I've seen E brought up is to criticize others' decisions, say a predecessor.
@mahoriR Things are rarely, if ever, either/or

Often, as a company or team

1. We are great at problem solving & not good enough at problem diagnosis

2. We want answers & don’t question our questions

3. We admire brute-force execution & don’t value calm strategic action

4. We prefer using a hammer & not a Swiss Army knife
@IzzaneeI One of them causes the other one 🙂

text: @sadhanarjam Hence “Most” in the tweet 5, and not “All”.

Lastly, these aren't rules that will be right 100% of the time.

Every situation is different. Context is everything. 

That's precisely why it's important to call them out: in many companies the opposite of these statements are blindly treated as rules.

That needs to change.
👍🏾

5/
You will learn more from avoiding major product mistakes than from making them.

Most product blunders & product PR issues can be foreseen & avoided, but aren’t. “Learning from mistakes” is important, but it’s often used by teams as an excuse for shoddy thinking & execution.

4/
It’s often a good thing if a Product Manager spends less time on product building activities.

Most PMs should spend at least 10% less time on product building activities. Allocate that time towards thinking about product distribution & incorporate that thinking in the product

3/
Product leaders shouldn’t feel pressured to secure early product wins in their first 90 days.

The net long-term value of “securing early wins” in a new product leadership job is more often negative than it is positive.

2/
You can get most B2B products right upfront. 

The practice of spending several years finding product-market fit shouldn’t be viewed as a virtuous activity that’s worthy of praise or admiration. It should usually be viewed as an option of last resort.

1/
Dates don’t matter as much as we pretend they do.

Hard launch dates are less about getting the product in users’ hands as quickly as possible and are more often a blunt tool used by management to ensure that people "are working well and are working hard”.

Note:
Some people will disagree with some of these points. If you’re one of them, this isn’t an attempt to change your mind. It's hard to change minds! Instead, I hope this is useful for folks who’ve felt that conventional wisdom is wrong but haven't yet found the words for it.
Five things I believe now about product work (that I did not believe 10 years ago):

don't mistake:

3 key properties of content:
Novel
Useful
Memorable

Their effect on the audience:
Novel + Useful → Enlighten me
Novel + Memorable → Engage me
Useful + Memorable → Empower me
Useful + Memorable + Novel → Transform me

First, decide the effect you want
Then, craft the content.

@coda_hq @shishirmehrotra @huddy @lshackleton Just posted:

https://t.co/SW5jiBxyDu

You can learn more about Eigenquestions (incl etymology & examples) in this post by @shishirmehrotra & @huddy
https://t.co/LImxFFbAX2

Many thanks to @shishirmehrotra for feedback on the difficult exercise of fitting an Eigenquestion example in 280 chars🙏🏾

Happy decision-making!

Combine WAYRTTD & Eigenquestions, apply them judiciously, and you & your team will be making significantly better product decisions that are more likely to stick.

https://t.co/tGIoGeweUw

Since I first learned about Eigenquestions a few years ago, I now spend about ½ the time making sure we have the right question for the decision. And then the remaining ½ can be allocated to a discussion of the pros/cons of the options

It feels slow, but it’s faster (and better)

Too often, decision-making starts with a background on metrics/feedback/etc, is followed by a set of options (clearly 3 is best :) ), & lastly it presents the recommended option. The group then litigates the fine details of the presented information to try & arrive at a decision.

One reason that Eigenquestions work so well is that they force us to better align our decision with our vision & strategy. A great reminder. So yes, "our catalog could be larger if we offered individually paid content to our members", but is that aligned with our vision & brand?

text:
An Eigenquestion example for Netflix

TVOD=Transactional Video On Demand
SVOD=Subscription VOD

Problem:
Given catalog(TVOD) >> catalog(SVOD), should we offer TVOD content? 

A super-complex decision!

The Eigenquestion:
Do we care more about catalog size or consumption friction?

For high-stakes product decisions, we need to step back & seek the Eigenquestion (creator: @shishirmehrotra).

The Eigenquestion is the question, which, if answered, provides the basis for answering most other substantial questions associated with this decision.

text:
For any difficult or high-impact product decision, we typically face a plethora of questions about what tradeoffs to make, what risks to take, how things might play out in practice, how this decision impacts our users, strategy, goals,...

text:
A disturbing trend I’ve noticed in the valley:

The number of people you manage is being equated with product scope & impact.

Being done by recruiters & hiring mgrs, and bigcos & startups.

Sets absolutely wrong incentives for people & have seen a number of problems due to this.

Important to also understand what is NOT strategy

https://t.co/9ntWNOadQs

Product Leadership role, responsibilities, & resources
https://t.co/uLHfmbALi2

@CoryChaplin @Altimor Regd desire for validation: we want others to accept & appreciate our point of view. We view an acceptance of our point of view as an acceptance of us. We (wrongly) assume that we therefore must express our point of view as early & as often as we can, hence speaking not listening

@Altimor a few reasons why listening is hard
- the fear of being wrong
- an inability to be present
- a desire for validation
- a lack of curiosity
- a sense of hierarchy
@george__mack @EricRWeinstein High Agency
@joshelman @pizzadelpopolo How was it? Haven’t had it before.
@peterrliem Indeed, life is hard & so is business
@neilkakkar Good point. It’s normally quite context-specific but happy to abstract it to general concepts if there’s interest.
@CoVisual @gibsonbiddle Love Gib’s work on strategy.

@neilkakkar Yeah, is at times not obvious in action but, over the last couple of years, I’ve developed a better eye for this. Can now usually spend an hour with the PM/Founder, asking a series of questions, and diagnose if the chief problem is Strategy, Execution, or People.
@snarayan Yeah, analogy not to be taken literally

Teams with a product strategy
vs.
Teams without a product strategy

 https://t.co/vSWQEHih1H
RT @collision: Delighted to welcome Dhivya Suryadevara to Stripe as our CFO! You may now begin your "well-oiled machine" and "stepping on t…
@thudayy Definitely a decent amount of luck.

@vinay_svk Yeah, I was experimenting with building & refining the ideas in the thread incrementally, based on the discussion. That’s why the successive tweets are a few hours apart. I don’t feel like it’s fully done, it’s hard to get these things to be super-precise & also easy to follow.
@trisweb Yeah, this framing makes a lot of sense. Love it!
@prankash Yeah I don’t love it. Needs more thinking.

@trisweb Yep, they’re quite hard to look at in isolation from each other, I’ve usually not separated the two in the past. There are of course aspects of Market that are outside of control of the _initial_ Strategy and that can work in negative or positive ways towards the Outcome.

@deporojue One can view "inputs" as a superset of "team" (e.g. who you hire, culture) but felt like team was important enough to call out on its own. Other inputs include user feedback, market research, usage metrics, requirements, prioritization, design, etc.

Takeaway:
Market > Strategy > Execution

Execution can be a limiter, but by itself cannot ensure large Outcomes

Strategy is a major amplifier for Outcomes, but is still dependent on Market

Market is essential for large Outcomes, assuming you've done fine on Strategy & Execution

@cavepainting In the sense that the Inputs determine Output quality, sure. IMO worth calling Inputs out separately though because of their importance (helps that this isn’t a real formula but more like a heuristic).
@vetrijedi Well said.
@Reddy_UT Thanks. Although it is not an actual formula, of course (and is imprecise in more ways than one) 😀

How's this as a heuristic?

Execution ^ Strategy  × Market = Outcomes

Execution = 𝒇 (inputs, outputs, team)

Strategy = 𝒇 (target segments, value proposition, strategic powers, distribution)

Market = 𝒇 (growth rate, competition, regulation, tech shifts, timing, pandemics...)
@dudeischill @chd_ch https://t.co/5LZ2tCrGCB

@odower Thanks! I share the "you are here" more generally in the context of proficiency in the role and point out if High Agency is getting in their way. I don't point to where they are in this 2x2, instead focus on the core skills & traits that can get them to a High Agency state.
@PerfectoPotenza Out of curiosity, what are the harder parts of explaining this to other groups?
@MattMHarriman 𝘔𝘢𝘳𝘬𝘦𝘵  = 𝒇(𝘨𝘳𝘰𝘸𝘵𝘩 𝘳𝘢𝘵𝘦, 𝘤𝘰𝘮𝘱𝘦𝘵𝘪𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯, 𝘳𝘦𝘨𝘶𝘭𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯, 𝘱𝘭𝘢𝘵𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘮 𝘰𝘳 𝘵𝘦𝘤𝘩 𝘴𝘩𝘪𝘧𝘵𝘴, 𝘵𝘪𝘮𝘪𝘯𝘨,...)

@deporojue Anyone can get lucky once or twice, but consistently successful teams do tend to acknowledge the market. That acknowledgment manifests in the form of a solid strategy i.e. market sizing, segmentation, targeting, positioning, value proposition. And that increases odds of success.

Now here's the really fascinating part:

Successful teams & Unsuccessful teams both tend to downplay or outright deny the role of the Market.

The latter deny it 𝘣𝘦𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘦 their failure, to feel more in control.

The former deny it 𝘢𝘧𝘵𝘦𝘳 their success, to look smarter.
@adrianh Yes, factors largely or fully outside of control + randomness
@joshviney Yes

Convenient illusion:
Inputs + Outputs = Outcomes

Inconvenient reality:
(Inputs + Outputs) × Market = Outcomes

text: @SandeepPotdar Equal but not the same means that they do different things but are not better or worse than other functions. Courage to be Disliked has more on this for ppl. Agree that successful companies can have IFH, doesn’t make it right. Hence also the point above about financial success.

Back to the top of this thread:

https://t.co/tnTQr3mE3z

10/
Hiring people just like you is a tempting but unsustainable way to replicate your thinking across a growing organization. Expressing & documenting your frameworks & principles is better. People can’t read your mind. Hence, repeat, repeat, repeat.

9/
As a leader, when you notice that people aren’t bringing their authentic selves to high-stakes meetings, their presentations are a little too polished, their intent is to impress not to inform & debate, don’t blame them. Ask what you’ve done to create this pressure & undo it.

8/
Some degree of uncertainty is a part and parcel of any complex business. The pressure for Certainty Theatrics at high-stakes meetings is at the root of many bad decisions.

7/
An exception to a pattern doesn’t make the exception the pattern.

It’s astonishing how often a rigorous discussion gets derailed when someone says in a meeting “well, but this doesn’t apply to <edge case X> [and therefore the pattern is useless]”

6/
Avoid Implicit Functional Hierarchy: Support isn’t inferior to Engineering, Product Mgmt isn’t superior to Sales. They're equal, but not the same. Implicit Functional Hierarchy might not prevent financial success, but it’ll definitely make your company Not-Fun for many people.

text:
5/
Drama is the silent killer of products, teams, and ultimately, company culture. And drama usually spreads top→down not bottom→up.

4/
Company culture has the same effect on people as money. It doesn't change people, but it grants them the license to be more of who they already are

For almost every trait, people can operate within a range, not just at a fixed point. Culture sets the point within their range.

3/
If a leader in your company unabashedly blames “incentives” as the reason for allowing major damage to customers/teams/culture, that person should not be a leader in your company.

2/
When one 𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘺  thinks about it, “strong opinions weakly held” doesn’t actually mean anything. It just gives people an excuse to be unrigorous & overbearing.

1/
Most products don’t HAVE to launch on a certain day. Use the designated launch date as a compass not as turn-by-turn navigations. Don’t drive your team or product into a ditch just to launch “on schedule”.

Some observations about organizations & culture, for modern leaders:

1/10

@NupurDaveAuthor @Joey_Heaney Perhaps, but X not being frustrated isn't the main goal. Doing the company-optimal thing is the main goal. And it might be company-optimal for X to do that extra work. Or to not update Y. WAYRTTD forces ppl to revisit the ingrained patterns that cause them to operate on autopilot
@george__mack Superb stuff. Thanks @george__mack
@St_Akomolafe Oh yes, I do like the And Why addition.
@The_Dark_Naik Ah, I don’t use it for users (or for others in general).
@bernard_cheng Basically that

@brianmac8500 👍🏾
I love the So What approach both for internal and external writing.

We can apply WAYRTTD in a meta way to help determine what thinking tool we should use for ourselves (e.g. 5 Whys vs WAYRTTD) by understanding the real function of such tools
https://t.co/R4z3WXB1mA https://t.co/AjNQvDiMfc

A couple of examples in <280 chars
https://t.co/JgPGNwgpM0 https://t.co/vzs0SFsrrk

Posting responses to some questions here
https://t.co/9zM9NRohZB https://t.co/WlvrGMOGA3

@peterrliem Thanks!

A well-documented lexicon that new hires are asked to review in their first few weeks can be helpful.

@peterrliem I hope to post about some more in the coming days e.g. WITMIT

The Eyeglass Store is another one that I posted about yesterday (in the Empathy thread).

@Joey_Heaney Product: Users complain that they forgot to cancel their annual subscription & ask for an email reminder 1 month before renewal. Email text prompts even some loyal users to cancel. With WAYRTTD: reminder isn't the real goal—perhaps allow users to cancel <N days after renewal?

@Joey_Heaney Interpersonal: Person X frustrated that Person Y (on a different team) isn't attending PX's weekly meeting. WAYRTTD shows that PY attending the wkly mtg isn't the real goal. Knowing the status of a shared project from PY is the real goal—can get it another way, say written update

@dcornish Related but not identical IMO. First principles reasoning can help find a good or novel solution to a problem. WAYRTTD can help clarify the problem itself. First principles reasoning may utilize WAYRTTD at various stages of problem solving. I could be missing something though.
@NarasimhanSri Heh, whatever works best to pause, reconsider, reframe is fine I suppose

@firesofmay I use it solely for myself (unlike what one might see on forums where it’s posed in response to a question from someone).

With others, I tend to ask “what’s your main goal here?”
@giridharvc7 Yes, similar, though I’ve personally found WAYRTTD easier to use.

WAYRTTD is the first thinking tool I learned at Stripe.

It stands for “What Are You 𝙍𝙚𝙖𝙡𝙡𝙮 Trying To Do”

WAYRTTD is a trusted friend anytime I’m confused about a problem.

And at some point, the WAYRTTD approach becomes hardwired ⇒ faster clarity & greater effectiveness.
@joshviney Thanks for expanding. Definitely curious if there are product companies that don't care about user empathy (since that would be very bad for their products), looking forward to the piece.

@SandeepPotdar My child is older now, which helps.

Other than that, one of the few upsides of the lockdown is more time at home.

text:
As a product person, you can scale major heights largely on the back of Empathy & High Agency.

(assuming no major flaws elsewhere)

Obviously there’s a LOT more to Product Management than just Empathy & High Agency.

And a LOT depends on the context of the company, product, team, etc.

But Empathy & High Agency are so valuable in the long run because of the leverage they create & their relative rarity.

Most valuable PM skill:
Empathy

Most valuable PM trait:
High Agency
@anubhavLFC Yep, user empathy vs coworker empathy.

@mar15sa Couldn’t agree more
https://t.co/C5zEmQyGct https://t.co/JE5KKyM1tM

@anubhavLFC 1. Ask questions that get people to describe a relatively common situation from the user's point of view e.g. "why is product X so successful?", "why do people often get frustrated in grocery checkout lines?"

2. Ask them if they need to take a break, to speak up if unclear, etc.

There are a few different types of empathy. I first came across these types in @indiyoung's book "Practical Empathy", one of my July 2020 book recos for product people.

This thread is about Cognitive Empathy.

Summary of the types, via @bryanzmijewski:
https://t.co/BgUzsbLuN8

@bryanzmijewski Very useful additions on types of empathy, thanks @bryanzmijewski!

This thread is largely referencing Cognitive Empathy. Will add that in the footnotes. Thanks again.

Even when summarizing Product Management in just 280 characters, we must include empathy. It's just that vital.

https://t.co/j1t3ol38SM

More empathy building tips for product people:

1. Get really good at listening

2. Use your own product

3. Use competitors' products (when you can)

4. Shadow folks in customer-facing roles (sales, support)

5. Approach problems with "a beginner's mind"
https://t.co/p9smc3vskb

text:
So folks, that’s all for today.

If you take away one message from this thread, let it be this:

Empathy isn’t a touchy-feely concept, it can be a superpower for product success.

And as a nice bonus, more individual & collective empathy will make your team & users happier.

👍🏾

Do the Eyeglass Store simulation often & this approach will get wired within you.

You’ll be able to apply it with ease at all granularities:
from a tricky pricing strategy decision down to being able to accurately predict people’s reactions to a given sentence in your blog post

When debating a product decision, enter the Eyeglass Store & try on different glasses.

Try one on for your Core User, another for the Casual User, then for the Buyer, for Competitors, for Press, for Regulators, for Channel Partners, and so on.

For each: observe, reflect, note. https://t.co/KdLGXtqMwM

Now, I will leave you with an empathy-building metaphor that's safe & useful for individuals & for teams: the Eyeglass Store.

In the Eyeglass Store, you’ll try different eyeglasses, each giving you a different view of the world around you and of the situation at hand. https://t.co/2kk3xw2GYY

Building respect for empathy requires building disrespect for these views:
• "Everyone thinks like I do"
• "Everyone may not think like me, but clearly they ought to"

And you’d be surprised how many intelligent people default to one of these views

Hence unlearning is crucial.

Now, the greatest impediment to building world-class empathy isn’t this knowledge or these tactics.

It’s our selves.

People often can’t get themselves to build respect for empathy as a skill & a tool.
👇🏾

When spending time with customers:
• Prioritize quality of insight over quantity of facts
• Ask more “why” questions than “what”/”how” questions
• Ask them how they’d react to certain scenarios, then ask them why

And then use the “whys” to form a better product hypothesis.

To build greater empathy:
• Understand how people think
• Understand how organizations operate

To do that:
• Learn the basics of psychology, behavioral economics, & cognitive biases 
• Be an objective & keen observer of org situations
• Spend time with customers
👇🏾

Empathy in action feels like magic. Like magic, it can be learned

text:
To sum it all up, lets frame these Productivity Principles as questions

Priority:
What to work on? What to ignore?

Presence:
How to get that work done?

Quality:
What does “done” look like? How good does it need to be?

Renewal:
How can I grow my effectiveness & efficiency?

📈

@benpickering This thread provides more info, but it’s basically tasks and projects that provide a significantly greater impact vs. the effort put into them:
https://t.co/bcdI3Jzqg8 https://t.co/J7zmV8YzJa
@ruturajd84 Added some follow up tweets to this thread that get to parts of what you're asking about.

On Renewal, learning & growth outside of ongoing work projects is often overlooked by ambitious people because they assume they must spend all available time on core projects.

For more on this, check out this 2½ min segment of a talk I gave in June:
https://t.co/ubx4n45sQp

On Quality, decide in advance what "done" looks like. Intentionally pick the quality of "done" you're aiming for in the given situation (rather than defaulting to a 10/10 bar for every single thing you do).

Example of how product teams can use this: 
https://t.co/KnoOwzxLbo

@deporojue Agree, ideally all employees would show many of these behaviors. It’s more about whats vital for managers to get right (the stuff above) vs. what’s vital for ICs. There are surely overlaps, but such a list for ICs would have many role-specific traits & behaviors that aren’t above

@thinkingbatt Thank you 🙏🏾 

I somehow always miss 13 🙂

Back to the top of this thread:

https://t.co/LslHlJ5DZh

That’s all for this thread.

If you’re a manager or want to be one, I wish you all the best in your journey. And if you are an individual contributor, I hope this context can be useful for you when you’re choosing your next role & manager.

❤️

I’ve personally gone from being a terrible manager 13 yrs ago to being just ok today. For many years in between, I actively avoided managing people because I knew I wasn’t good at it & didn’t enjoy it. That changed for me as I learned & discovered some of what you have just read.

15/
Last but not least: 
Good managers value clear thinking, sound judgment, & wisdom. They try their best, but also realize they (& others) are fallible & anyone can have a bad day. They know that their own growth as a manager isn’t a binary quantity, it’s a continuous process.

14/
Good managers are confident & secure in their role. 
They model High Agency.
They have a mature attitude & avoid pettiness.
They know it’s fine to express vulnerability.
They say “I don’t know” when that’s true.
They love learning.
They exude presence.

12/
Good managers can discern good intent from bad. They have zero tolerance for self-serving behavior that sabotages the team or the company, even if it’s coming from an otherwise highly competent team member.

11/
Good managers don’t have just one go-to management style nor do they have a notion of “THE ideal employee”. Good managers aim to create an inclusive & optimal environment for each individual, based on their specific strengths, weaknesses, preferred style of learning & working

text:
10/ 
Good managers are proactive about their team members’ career growth. They don’t dread career conversations with team members, they actively invite such conversations.

9/
Good managers consistently get results through their team. 

They have high standards for inputs, outputs, and outcomes. They aren’t satisfied with just meeting the minimum permissible bar for metrics, product quality, customer satisfaction, team collaboration, and so on.

8/
Good managers understand that the long game is all about people

They put an individual’s mental & physical well-being above short term OKRs & results. They pay keen attention to a team member’s feelings in addition to their spoken words & can detect dissonance between the two

7/
Good managers put their team members above their own self-interest when the two are in conflict.

6/
Good managers know that fixing broader company culture is an important part of their role as a designated leader within the company.

5/
Good managers know that, above all else, they are agents of their company. Their default mode is to make and facilitate company-optimal choices.

4/
Good managers use their eloquence, charisma, and writing skills as tools, never as weapons.

Good managers address context first, then content

They don’t just stick a new process as a band-aid over deep culture wounds & hope that the pain goes away. They know that most problems are interpersonal problems at their core. They have a knack for identifying the root cause

2/
Good managers listen, then listen some more, and then some more.

1/
Good managers are skilled at asking questions that give their team members a new perspective on the problem and reach the right solution on their own.

Good managers, what they do, how they think & act. 

A thread👇🏾

@remi_guyot Yes. Vision is important, but the strategy should be aligned-enough with the vision so that you usually don’t need to consult the vision for most product decisions.
@Alessandro_Cos It’s important but in my view it isn’t a raw input, rather the main intermediate output when one combines most of the factors above.

@zachtratar Some phrases that can help:
“I hear you”
“You might be right”
“My tweet isn’t meant to solve all problems”
“All the best to you”

First two for the more reasonable ones, last two for the less reasonable ones.

@tcordrey @i2pi Ah, can you say more? Very intrigued.
@OKibarogullari For some tweets, one has to assume the presence of integrity. Big assumption, I know, but such is life when we get to speak 280 characters at a time.

@i2pi Yes, I've seen that too. Though such teams (*if* they're competent & consistent) tend to over time build better dashboards & analytics so they don't have to slow down often because "data isn't available", "don't know how to measure this", "we can't agree, so blame data", etc.

Key inputs for product decisions:
1. Data
2. Customer feedback
3. Technical effort
4. Strategy
5. Industry landscape
6. Instinct

Rely heavily on 1-3?
Can move fast, but often too incremental.

Rely heavily on 4-6?
Can make big impact, but often fail prematurely.

Hence, balance.

@arunninghacker @PaulWebSec Intent is a combination of mindset & skill.

Intent = (Integrity × Clear thinking) ÷ Selfishness

Or put another way.

Intent = Integrity × Ownership mindset × Clear thinking

Intent trounces all other skills. Here's why:

𝙂𝙤𝙤𝙙  Intent × Persuasion = Influence
Influence × Execution = Impact
Impact × Consistency = Success

𝘽𝙖𝙙  Intent × Persuasion = Manipulation
Manipulation × Execution = Collective Harm
Collective Harm × Consistency = Misery

text: @MJB_SF @trisweb @johncutlefish I wish more product managers took the time to really understand marketing theory & concepts. For instance, the CPG marketing people have decades ago figured out things that PMs in tech learn the hard way on the job e.g. after a number of product failures due to bad segmentation.

@johncutlefish Yep. Your point also reminded me that these days we refuse to accept uncertainty as a normal state in any sufficiently complex business & product situation. We seek great certainty or feel the pressure for certainty-theatrics in product review meetings, for instance.

@techwraith I hear you, perhaps that's part of it. Though I also do see talented product people feeling like they must use data for all decisions, instead of feeling free to mix data+instinct in ways that make most sense in a given situation. I wish such folks trusted their instincts more.

@obaidfar This needs to be recognized by middle and senior management, since they’re the ones who can effect changes.

At the lower levels of the org, perhaps getting the ability to run a pilot to prove value of a different model could be a start.

The evolution of product decision making in the valley:

10 years ago, I thought we weren’t using data as much as we should.

These days, I catch myself thinking that we aren’t using our instincts as much as we should.

Important point 👇🏾 about team size, scope, and autonomy

Related thread, on identifying problematic senior leadership archetypes during the hiring process (because preventing the problem > solving the problem)

https://t.co/hHbEDssH7k https://t.co/qycTFWNAfU
@wincewong Agree, #4 is a self-centered version of what I think you’re getting at.
@kurtp77 I’ll try writing it down. Thanks for the suggestion.
@MotwaniSuhas @TheAmolWalvekar Love it 😍
@skamille Yeah, very valid point - the alternative I was considering was Leadership-Pleaser but didn’t go with that. The “kiss ass up, kick ass down” framing is very evocative, thanks!

And when we give a name to a collection of such behaviors, we make it much easier for teams & senior leadership to confront the issues & talk about the reality of the situation. 

And that can be the first & the most important step towards making our company better 👍🏾

Now, I know these anti-patterns look “obviously bad” when framed like this. That should be no surprise, because that’s exactly what happens when we filter out organizational noise to understand the root causes, the modus operandi, & the pernicious effects of these behaviors.

7/ The Rearrange-Deck-Chairs Manager

An offshoot of #4, this is typically an org leader who often gets promoted without achieving actual results. Engages in constant process changes & org re-shuffles to demonstrate will & effort (& buy more time). Team suffers constant whiplash.

6/ The People-Pleaser Manager

Treats pleasing peers & superiors as existentially important. Can be perceived as very collaborative & effective in some company cultures, but is bad for team members because will always prioritize pleasing peers/superiors over valid team interests.

5/ The Lets-Be-Buddies Manager

A relationships-person who thinks that a good manager must be a best friend of his direct reports. Often is a strong advocate. Is problematic because usually not possible to establish same type of rapport with everyone on the team, makes favorites.

text:
4/ The Means-To-An-End Manager

Views team members as agents whose main purpose is to further his own goals & career. Very business-like in dealings. Achieves short-term results. Team is usually very unhappy. With charisma, may be viewed by company leadership as “top talent”.

3/ The Look-How-Smart-I-Am Manager

Enjoys bringing up his team members’ flaws with trusted peers & with his own manager (“can you believe Alice said 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘵 in a client meeting?”). Typically is not yet feeling secure in his own role as a manager & feels the need for validation.

2/ The Be-More-Like-Me Manager

Usually someone who was very competent as an IC & hasn’t yet learned effective mentorship. Can be frustrating for team members who have different or complementary skills because much of the advice can be boiled down to “I used to just do X, Y, Z”.

1/ The Make-Common-Enemies Manager

Loves talking about how certain other departments in the company are so incompetent. Can get very popular with team members as a result. Very poisonous for the org. Might not have overtly malicious intent, often just ignorant. Usually coachable

Some managers are clearly great, some are clearly terrible. It’s quite easy to spot these extremes.

But how can we spot the 𝘢𝘱𝘱𝘢𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘵𝘭𝘺-𝘨𝘰𝘰𝘥 𝘣𝘶𝘵 𝘢𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘺-𝘷𝘦𝘳𝘺-𝘣𝘢𝘥  managers at our company?

A thread of 7 Manager Anti-Patterns: https://t.co/nncFPa5lMR

@justindross @avibryant Yeah, the GM hack isn't great because even good PMs might not know how to manage eng/business teams, but they aren't self-aware about that.

I like having wide comp bands whose high end can be used for exceptional ICs. That way, comp is not the reason to seek more scope/titles.

As a bonus:

This can also work online

(if the other party is engaging in good faith. I know, that's a big *if*)

@SandeepPotdar Yeah, those are useful. I've found that dropping the "good/great question" part is key because the right approach for absurd questions is to not to give them validation on their initial question.

@numberlock11 "Thanks for sharing that perspective. I'm going to think about it some more. I'd suggest we both take some time to do this and reconvene. I don't want to draw any hasty conclusions or make a premature decision."
@numberlock11 "Thanks for elaborating. I still don't follow. Say more please."

An effective tactic when facing an absurd question:

Just say “Can you please elaborate on that”

Why it works:
Shifts the power dynamic
Forces the other party to reconsider their stance, while still saving face
Gives you more space to formulate a calm, rational response

Win-Win

What is Product Editing?

I've adapted it from @rabois's general framing on Editing:
https://t.co/gXQrrk8TXW

Check out this thread for more on Product Editing for PM leaders:
https://t.co/MExHg1OFOx

Meta-Execution is about setting up the goals, plans, frameworks & cross-org contracts that allow your PMs to execute better.

Key aspects of Meta-Execution:
Goal-setting
Prioritization
Decision-making & facilitation
Cross-org navigation
Progress tracking
Status communication⬆️
See 👇🏾 for further reading and answers to the FAQs I've seen thus far

text:
Follow up:

Almost any thing, if done in excess, can be at least as bad thing as the complete absence of said thing.

The call to action here is about being somewhere in between having zero true knowledge of your competition to tracking or mimicking every micro-move of theirs.

@sid_chilling I don't have a formal methodology, but for most verticals this information is available
-on the web
-via conversations with industry experts 
-via getting market intelligence from one's Sales team (what are you seeing in the market?, where are we winning/losing deals & why?...)
@bdesarnauts Agreed 💯

In sum:

Understand your competition upfront. (it won’t take 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘵 much time)

Use this understanding as one of the inputs to your product strategy.

Execute on this strategy to build a differentiated product. 

Stay up-to-date on the competitive landscape.

👍🏾All the best!

Create a table with these factors for at least your top 3 competitors (est time: <1 week)

Refresh it at least every 6 months (est time: 1 day)

In return, will save months/years of pain

And (if it matters) you'll come across as more competent to your Board/CEO/Sr. Management
📈

Here are the basics that you need to understand about your competitors:

• Target customer segments
• Product value proposition
• Inherent advantages
• Deficiencies & weaknesses
• Go-to-market approach

So, what should you do as a startup founder, product leader, or product manager?

I know you're super-busy. You’ve got so much other stuff to do. 

So let’s 80/20 this <insert PM joke>.

You don't need to go get a PhD in your competition.

The basics will take you quite far.

Mindsets that get in the way:
• Overly eager to “just start building”
• Falsely equating “understand” with “copy”
• Self-talk of “skate where the puck is going”

Exacerbated by beliefs such as “Steve Jobs didn’t look at 𝘩𝘪𝘴 competition”. Don’t fall prey to Survivorship Bias

@el_indiano 🙏🏾👍🏾
No rule is valid for every single situation in life. Except this rule.
Last but not least (for now), very important note👇🏾

15/
If you choose to understand one 𝘮𝘰𝘳𝘦  cognitive bias, let it be Confirmation Bias.

14/
If you choose to understand just one cognitive bias, let it be the Fundamental Attribution Error.

12/
Technologies change, platforms change, office signs change, centers of gravity change. The one thing that remains constant is the people. Always optimize for the people.

11/
When in doubt about where to take a job, pick the place with the better people. Even if it ends up being the wrong bet, you’ll still be more fulfilled with your work.

10/
Whatever industry you’re in is probably smaller than you imagine it is. People talk. Don’t burn bridges over the small stuff.

9/
The chief indicator of authentic confidence isn’t bravado. It’s the person’s openness to discovering why they’re wrong.

8/
When you find someone inspiring, try to separate their content and their charisma. And if it’s the charisma that inspires, be very careful.

7/
Learn from everyone & everything. Don’t view people as better or worse than you, worthy or unworthy of teaching you. And if something doesn’t fully resonate, don’t reject it wholesale. Try extracting the useful bits & learn from those. Wisdom is everywhere, if you can spot it

6/
We spend so much time & energy trying to give our children the comforts 𝘸𝘦  never had, that we often become the absentee parents that our children will wish 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘺  never had.

5/
Legacy is overrated. So is impact.

4/
There is a gentler, more satisfying measure of success than Titles, Money, Prestige, Impact. 

Measure success by the optionality you have with your time.

Just a few notes to myself (a driven & ambitious person):

@LithosProject @PM4Imposters This is a good question, but it's so context dependent that any suggestion/advice is 50% likely to be very bad/harmful.

IME, I haven't seen cases of clearly messed up ethics in senior management, but I have seen cases of different perspectives on what's the ethical thing to do.

@pankaj013 Basing decisions solely on metrics is exactly the problem. It's something product leaders should help steer the organization away from, during good times and bad.

https://t.co/Ye5sA4foYq

@marctollin I completely agree, there could be dozens of reasons for product failure and sometimes it's just because of bad luck. 
The original tweet isn't about product failures being bad. It's about leaders calling out metrics, incentives, or following the process as an excuse for failure.
@avinashxw A record of always shipping on time is not a major determinant of long term product success in my experience. Not something to sweat in my opinion, unless it's a chronic issue.
@JonathanAGraham @dlkumar1 Heh, that might be one of the better excuses for a failed product (but not the other two). Pursue a bold company-level vision, doesn't work out, it happens.
@regulatorynerd Is Caltrain actually just cake?

@raghro Ah, I prefer using the same starter questions & then drilling into specifics depending on their initial answer. With the same starter questions, I can be better calibrated across candidates, while still giving each candidate the room to demonstrate their unique POV (or so I hope)

Public Service Announcement:

If you’re in a product leadership role & your product fails or causes major user damage or a PR fiasco, “metrics made me do it” or “incentives made me do it” isn’t a good excuse

Exercising sound judgment & making hard decisions is literally THE job.
@diviacaroline Hmm... it should work within one full rotation. But not sure if there's an industry standard for this stuff 🤷🏾‍♂️
@diviacaroline Turning the spout counterclockwise usually works for me.

Why this works?

The initial question should just be a starting prompt

Careful listening, your follow up questions & their response to those questions give much greater signal

Helps you look beyond the “polished answers” that senior folks tend to have for the standard questions

A litmus test I’ve used when devising interview questions for senior roles:

If this question were leaked on the internet, would I still continue to use it?

And if my answer is No, it isn't a good question in the first place. Discard it.
@ankurnagpal Niiice, congrats to you and the team!
😆Another brilliant video by @yayalexisgay https://t.co/sBxU4HPXwN
@jxu577 👋🏾 Oh yes, I very much do.

@benthom_as Metrics aren't bad by themselves, but an obsession with metrics over everything else (the hammer for every nail) can lead to bad product consequences (for the user, for the company, or both).

https://t.co/L8IjOjWBkM
@vivek43185236 Nothing wrong with aiming to do things fast, but there is such as a thing as going recklessly fast and not mapping out where we want to go and why in the first place.

@acmnamin Agree, it's hard. It helps if teams can remember that it's Velocity they should be after, not raw Speed. And that they should play the long game. A 3 week "delay" in starting will rarely if ever kill a product.
@gem_ray Important to also have fun when writing this stuff 😀

@jxu577 Agreed, thx for sharing. In a way, it's a special case of Maslow's Hammer (where the goal/metric is the hammer), but it's definitely common by itself. The other thing you allude to is user behavior change—teams often assume that of course users will change, only to find it's hard

text:
What to do?

The ultimate onus for avoiding these traps is on PM/Eng/Design leaders in middle mgmt. They need to recognize & call out whenever they see these issues crop up: upwards (pushing back on sr. mgmt) AND downwards (educating their product teams). 

No other easy answer💪🏾

7/ Russian Roulette for products

We don’t account enough for scenarios that could, under certain conditions, lead to a catastrophic outcome for our product or a PR nightmare for our company.

Usually found in companies where “following orders” or “just get it done” is rewarded.

6/ The Authority Approval Bias

We devise product strategies, conceive product features & propose product plans based largely on what we think is going to either confirm the beliefs held by those in a position of authority at the company or more easily get us approval to proceed.

text:
5/ Maslow’s Hammer

We use a framework, a skill, or a proxy that we are most comfortable with (or one that our company endorses) even when its utility is limited or counterproductive in a specific product context.

Example: FB uses metrics as a hammer for most product problems.

4/ The Focusing Illusion for products

When we talk to customers about the problem that our product solves, we overestimate its severity & get surprised when the customer doesn’t end up buying or using our product. Any problem will feel more critical while you’re talking about it

text:
3/ The IKEA Effect for products

Usually applicable to an 𝘦𝘹𝘪𝘴𝘵𝘪𝘯𝘨 product that’s struggling, we base our 𝘤𝘶𝘳𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘵 product decisions on 𝘱𝘢𝘴𝘵 product execution because we’re too attached to the work we’ve already put in & don’t want it to "have been for nothing".

2/ The Bias-for-Building Fallacy

We don’t take the time to thoroughly understand the problem, domain, competitors & other determinants of product success because we feel compelled to be in constant motion. We tell ourselves we must begin building & just iterate based on feedback

text:
1/ The Execution Orientation Fallacy

We craft flawed product strategies & make suboptimal product decisions because we base these decisions on what we know we can easily execute today.

Shortsightedness & Low Agency typically cause this fallacy.

I see this one all the time.

Why do smart product people & teams often build products with mediocre or no impact?

A cautionary thread of biases and fallacies we encounter when building products👇🏾

text: @Titogelo Having people with sound judgment is very important, particularly for early-stage startups. So any process whose premise is that people will not exercise sound judgment is at least a yellow flag for me (and depending on its degree, can be a red flag).
@weswinham Yep, not all processes are bad.

Companies that heavily rely on process as a safeguard against incompetence are like that person who just pops aspirin for his recurring headaches.

Adding process might give you satisfaction in the moment, but it can be fatal if you never diagnose & fix the underlying issues.
